Data ScienceVERSION 3: AN INTRODUCTION TO

This document excerpt is the preface and introduction to the third edition of "Data Science: An Introduction." The book, authored by Jeffrey Stanton with contributions from Robert W. De Graaf, was developed for Syracuse University‚Äôs Certificate of Data Science program at the School of Information Studies. It outlines the core focus of the book, which centers around the multifaceted process of data science, encompassing activities such as data collection, preparation, analysis, visualization, management, and preservation. The preface highlights the book‚Äôs distribution under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 license, granting users the freedom to copy, distribute, and adapt the work, provided they maintain attribution to the authors and adhere to the license terms. Specifically, commercial use is prohibited. The excerpt also provides contact information for the author, Jeffrey Stanton (jmstanto@syr.edu), for reporting errors or omissions. Furthermore, it directs readers to a website (http://jsresearch.net/wiki/projects/teachdatascience) where a PDF version of the book and associated code examples are available. A special acknowledgment is given to Ashish Verma for his assistance in revising Chapter 10. The book‚Äôs development reflects the growing importance of data science as a distinct field of work, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive understanding of its various components. The document clearly establishes the book's purpose and licensing details, setting the stage for the subsequent content.

Key Concepts:

  • Data Science refers to an emerging area of work concerned with the collection, preparation, analysis, visualization, management, and preservation of data.
  • The book is distributed under a Creative Commons license, requiring attribution and prohibiting commercial use.
  • The book was developed for the CertiÔ¨Åcate of Data Science program at Syracuse University‚Äôs School of Information Studies.
